author: hikariws
content: An address isn't "created" on the network, an address is just the public key. When a blockchain is started, all public keys in the world have 0 balance. Creating a wallet is generating a random private key and calculating its public key. To write any transaction on the blockchain on an address, we need that address' private key to sign that transaction. U can send funds to any address, but if the private key of that address is unknown to everybody or lost by its owner, that fund will be untouchable until somebody calculates the private key for it.

author: hikariws
content: If u sent funds to an address and saw it on BSC, it means u sent it in BSC instead of ETH network. Every modern ETH wallet supports choosing the network and all updated web-based service should be able to identify which network we're using and warn us if we're using the wrong one.
